critique: This executive order establishes a Radiation Policy Council to coordinate federal radiation protection policy. It involves multiple federal agencies and aims to resolve conflicts and ensure effective communication with states and Congress. It does not obviously lean liberal or conservative. It doesn't directly address immigration. It could be seen as expanding executive power slightly by creating a new council, but it also includes checks and balances by involving multiple agencies and requiring reports. It centralizes authority at the federal level. It balances national security and civil liberties by focusing on radiation protection. It involves government intervention in radiation protection. It doesn't directly address social inclusion.
